headline.main: Bulls Have Championships, Jazz Has the Home Court

results.snippet: The Bulls will leave the plane and take their first giant steps of this finals appearance with the trepidation of an astronaut. There will be excitement, but uncertainty as they plant themselves on the Delta Center floor in Salt Lake City for Game 1...
results.lead_paragraph: The Bulls will leave the plane and take their first giant steps of this finals appearance with the trepidation of an astronaut. There will be excitement, but uncertainty as they plant themselves on the Delta Center floor in Salt Lake City for Game 1 Wednesday in a land that might as well be another planet this year. The Utah Jazz has changed, from the climate of its confidence to the topography of its mind-set. This is not the same Jazz team that was at first awestruck before stretching Chicago to six games in last year's National Basketball Association finals. And this is not the same swaggering Bulls team that typically enters the finals with all the advantages of the upper crust. They still have Michael Jordan, but the Jazz holds the home-court advantage.

headline.main: Shuttle Pays a Final Call To the Celestial Dragonfly

results.snippet: ASTRONAUTS report that one of the most striking visions in space is approaching the Russian Mir space station, which first appears as a distant point of light. Drawing closer, Mir -- with its cruciform configuration of modules and arrays of wing-like...
results.lead_paragraph: ASTRONAUTS report that one of the most striking visions in space is approaching the Russian Mir space station, which first appears as a distant point of light. Drawing closer, Mir -- with its cruciform configuration of modules and arrays of wing-like solar panels -- slowly begins to resemble a giant cosmic insect glowing bright against the blackness of space. Now, visits to this celestial dragonfly by American space shuttle crews are about to end. After being a focus of American manned space activity for the last three years, stays on Mir are about to join Gemini capsules and Saturn rockets as historical artifacts of the nation's space program.

results.abstract: Commencement speakers this year are turning to Nelson Mandela for words of inspiration to share with graduates; spokesman at South African Embassy in Washington says Mandela never said words that were posted on Internet and attributed to his 1994 inaugural address; says passage is from Marianne Williamson's 1992 book A Return to Love (S)

headline.main: Commencements; Quoting Mandela, but for One Problem

results.snippet: Commencement speakers this year are turning to Nelson Mandela for words of inspiration to share with graduates. Hillary Rodham Clinton quoted the President of South Africa in her address to Howard University, as did the astronaut Mae C. Jemison in...
results.section_name: Education; Books; New York and Region
results.lead_paragraph: Commencement speakers this year are turning to Nelson Mandela for words of inspiration to share with graduates. Hillary Rodham Clinton quoted the President of South Africa in her address to Howard University, as did the astronaut Mae C. Jemison in her speech to Duquesne University. Johnnetta B. Cole, the former president of Spelman College, cited him to Mount Holyoke. The wisdom: ''Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness, that most frightens us.''

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery is launched, beginning last American mission to Russia's Mir space station; Col Charles J Prescourt heads crew, which includes Americans Comdr Dominic L Gorie, Comdr Wendy B Lawrence, Dr Franklin R Chang-Diaz, Dr Janet Lynn Kavandi and Russian Valery V Ryumin; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Begins America's Last Mission to Mir

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery blasted through hazy, hot Florida skies today on the last American mission to the Mir space station, a flight eagerly anticipated by the astronaut Andrew Thomas, who has spent more than four months on the Russian outpost...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery blasted through hazy, hot Florida skies today on the last American mission to the Mir space station, a flight eagerly anticipated by the astronaut Andrew Thomas, who has spent more than four months on the Russian outpost and is ready to come home. The shuttle, carrying a crew of five Americans and a Russian, lifted off at 6:06 P.M. at the beginning of a narrow launching window and rose on a thunderous plumb of tan smoke to start its two-day sprint to Mir.

results.abstract: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani visits Public School 1 in Chinatown to introduce children's book written and published for him called What Will You Be? book was written and illustrated by Kristin Doney; it was published by New York City Public/Private Initiatives Inc and made possible in part by $25,000 grant from Goldman, Sachs & Co; book will be donated to all elementary school libraries and all branches of New York Public Library; drawing (M)

headline.main: In Children's Book, Giuliani Puts Smiles on Cabbies and Vendors

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NEW YORK CITY PUBLIC/PRIVATE INITIATIVES INC

results.snippet: Cabbies, street vendors and jaywalkers. These may not sound like a few of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's favorite things, but they all wear big grins in a new picture book written and published for the Mayor.    The cover of ''What Will You Be?'' says...
results.lead_paragraph: Cabbies, street vendors and jaywalkers. These may not sound like a few of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's favorite things, but they all wear big grins in a new picture book written and published for the Mayor. The cover of ''What Will You Be?'' says it is ''A story by: Mayor Rudy Giuliani'' but he is also the star, appearing in nine photographs and drawings. The book follows his real-life yellow Labrador, Goalie, as he romps through a buffet of career choices, encouraging youngsters to aim high and study hard, even if the curriculum is ''The Joy of Napping.''

results.abstract: Ohio's 17-member Congressional delegation, both Democrats and Republicans, contends that Sen John Glenn of Ohio possesses 'every attribute of a champion,' and asks General Mills to honor Glenn by featuring his visage on box of Wheaties; photo (S)

headline.main: Glenn Is Nominated For Box of Wheaties

results.snippet: The way Ohio's Congressional delegation sees it, Senator John Glenn possesses ''every attribute of a champion.'' That's the phrasing 17 members, Democrats and Republicans, used recently when they asked General Mills to honor Mr. Glenn by featuring...
results.lead_paragraph: The way Ohio's Congressional delegation sees it, Senator John Glenn possesses ''every attribute of a champion.'' That's the phrasing 17 members, Democrats and Republicans, used recently when they asked General Mills to honor Mr. Glenn by featuring his square-jawed, all-American visage on a box of Wheaties. Mr. Glenn, a Democrat and the first American to orbit Earth, is retiring this year and has talked the National Aeronautics and Space Administration into letting him suit up again, in October, at the robust age of 77. This time he will fly aboard a shuttle mission.

results.abstract: Discovery space shuttle completes its final mision to Russian space station, bringing Mir's seventh and last American astronaut, Dr Andrew Thomas, home from his stay of four and a half months in orbit (M)

headline.main: Space Shuttle Returns Safely From the Last of Its Missions to Mir

results.snippet: The space shuttle completed its final mission to the Russian space station today, bringing Mir's seventh and last American tenant home from his stay of four and a half months in Earth orbit.    ''I want to thank you all for bringing me home and...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle completed its final mission to the Russian space station today, bringing Mir's seventh and last American tenant home from his stay of four and a half months in Earth orbit. ''I want to thank you all for bringing me home and giving me a great ride,'' the long-duration astronaut, Andrew Thomas, said minutes after a bumpy but safe landing aboard the shuttle Discovery.

results.abstract: Interview with Sen John Glenn, who at 77 years old looks ahead to his return to outer space, while also looking back on his 24 years in Senate; Glenn's return to space in October will also mark end to his Senate career; says joy of looking forward to weightlessness is rivaled by delight of never again having to engage in political fund-raising; photos (M)

headline.main: Glenn Is Ready to Say Goodbye to All That

results.snippet: Senator John Glenn, the merriest commuter on Capitol Hill, was talking of the spaceship he will soon be riding and the joy of weightlessness, which for him is rivaled by the delight of never again having to engage in political fund-raising, the bane...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John Glenn, the merriest commuter on Capitol Hill, was talking of the spaceship he will soon be riding and the joy of weightlessness, which for him is rivaled by the delight of never again having to engage in political fund-raising, the bane of his earthly existence these past 24 years. ''I'd rather wrestle a gorilla than ask anybody for another 50 cents,'' the Senator growled rather happily amid busy days of commuting between space-travel training in Houston and the astronaut's requisite renunciation of the earthly baggage called politics.

results.abstract: Thomas Mallon article on NASA's plan to let Sen John Glenn, who made historic space flight in 1962, return to space on STS-95 shuttle mission at age 77; Glenn insists aim is to spur research on aging, interview; photos (L)
results.snippet: ''One of the neat things about being a commander,'' says Lieut. Col. Curtis L. Brown Jr., ''is when you take rookies into space and you see their face after the main engine shutdown and you're in orbit. You never forget that.'' In October, if all...
results.lead_paragraph: ''One of the neat things about being a commander,'' says Lieut. Col. Curtis L. Brown Jr., ''is when you take rookies into space and you see their face after the main engine shutdown and you're in orbit. You never forget that.'' In October, if all goes as planned, Colonel Brown will fly his fifth shuttle mission with one crew member who may have that same look, not from the novelty of the experience but from distant memory. If Charles Lindbergh had climbed into a cockpit two years before Ronald Reagan became President, he would have been 77, the age John Glenn will be when he makes his second spaceflight. Indeed, to understand the peculiarity of this flight, it helps to do one more piece of math: we are now further away in time from Glenn's first mission than that mission was from Lindbergh's solo flight across the Atlantic.

results.abstract: Kathleen McAuliffe article on uncertainties of prenatal testing; says tests like amniocentesis can detect genetic abnormalities, but they have also become adept at detecting tiny imperfections whose implications vary wildly; says interpreting their meaning is not a precise science; says many couples are forced to make decision on continuing or terminating pregnancy on their own, in the dark; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

headline.main: A Little Knowledge, a Lot of Agony

results.snippet: FIVE years ago, a much-wanted pregnancy at age 37 prompted me to seek prenatal testing. I had of course been prepared for the possibility of bad news. But the test results posed a harrowing dilemma unlike anything I had anticipated or been warned to...
results.lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, a much-wanted pregnancy at age 37 prompted me to seek prenatal testing. I had of course been prepared for the possibility of bad news. But the test results posed a harrowing dilemma unlike anything I had anticipated or been warned to expect. What is more, as a medical writer, I had entered the testing procedure better informed than most expectant parents. Yet I became a prime example of how people can be unwittingly steamrolled by the advancing juggernaut of genetic science.
